ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had some in person meetings, very few though.

This course met three times per week for synchronous sessions, in addition to one individual conversation with the teaching assistant each week. On the days in which the class did not meet synchronously over Zoom, we were assigned work for asynchronous sessions.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Learned more hebrew grammar, particularly speaking in the future. This was really cool

The course reviewed the present and past tenses of Modern Hebrew, and introduced me to the future tense. We also covered an immense amount of vocabulary that is pertinent to conversational capabilities, as well as Israeli culture and society.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Shiri is super understanding and very kind professor. Definitely makes sure we do the work but when we need extra time she is super super understanding which is a great strength of the class and the program in general!
The workload for this course is very high and it is extremely difficult to do a language over zoom.

Given the circumstances of a virtual semester, this course was able to function quite successfully over Zoom. The strengths were the sense of community, the accessibility of the instructors, and the diversity of assignments.

Strength: material was relevant, actually learned the language. Not just learning about hebrew but how to actually speak it.
Weakness: Too much work, a lot of which did not go a long way in helping us learn.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual was very successful. Honestly everything is great.
The professor did a great job of using zoom, but there needs to be a change in the type of work that is done and the way that it is submitted.

The split between synchronous and asynchronous sessions was very conducive to my learning. If our foreign language class had met synchronously every day, it would have been difficult to manage. I appreciated how we used the synchronous sessions to practice our speaking abilities through engaging activities.

Class size of about 6 people was ideal. The ability to complete assignments on our own time was good, too, allowing us to just converse in class. The walking and chatting assignments were a great, low-stress way to practice.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Good class. Learned a lot. Just gotta put in the work but definitely prepares you well and makes you a better student of the language.
I would recommend this course. All languages are a lot of work, at least with Hebrew you get an understanding faculty and a close community among classmates.

Yes, I would certainly recommend this course to another student. While the workload was high, I learned so much and feel significantly more confident with my Hebrew abilities. The class also had a fantastic sense of community, even over Zoom, which contributed to my comfortability.

ABSOLUTELY! Shiri is a wonderful and caring teacher, who makes sure everyone in her class is getting what they need. It is true that you might have to do a lot of work, but I think it's completely worth it, and both Shiri (the prof) and Naama (the TF) support you all the way through.

Yes, because we should all learn hebrew. That said, it felt very class-like which made it kinda stressful and took away from what should have been a low stakes environment. Easier than L5 French but harder than L2 Hebrew so think carefully about the balance of prioritizing learning hebrew, not being stressed, and doing well in the class.
